title: How to Create a 'Polaroid' Snapshot With Poladroid

steps.headline: Go to the website and download Poladroid.
steps.description:
Some of its features are:
ease to use
square frame
colour shift
vignetting
premature aging

steps.headline: Install it by [Unzip-a-File-or-Folder-With-Winzip unzipping] it and then running the installation file.
Double click on the icon.
steps.description: The above screenshot is what you will see next (results may vary depending on your desktop).

steps.headline: Drag your picture to the brown area in front of the camera.
steps.description: When the picture is 'taken', you will hear the whirring sound of a Polaroid machine. As the picture 'develops', you will see it happen.

steps.headline: Wait several minutes until the photo is finished.
steps.description: Hint: if you want to speed up the process, shake your image from right to left. Once the image is ready, a bell rings and the image is marked up with a red cross. That will enable you to delete the picture easily, if you don't like the results. The final file (in JPEG format) will be generated in the same folder than the original image or your ‘Images’ folder, depending on your settings in the preferences.

steps.headline: Change the destination folder.
steps.description: If you will be doing a lot of pictures, it might be a good idea to have them all go into the same place. To do that, click on the blue icon  and go to Settings. Make your adjustments there.

text:
Go to the website and download Poladroid. Some of its features are:
ease to use
square frame
colour shift
vignetting
premature aging Install it by [Unzip-a-File-or-Folder-With-Winzip unzipping] it and then running the installation file.  Double click on the icon. The above screenshot is what you will see next (results may vary depending on your desktop). Drag your picture to the brown area in front of the camera. When the picture is 'taken', you will hear the whirring sound of a Polaroid machine. As the picture 'develops', you will see it happen. Wait several minutes until the photo is finished. Hint: if you want to speed up the process, shake your image from right to left. Once the image is ready, a bell rings and the image is marked up with a red cross. That will enable you to delete the picture easily, if you don't like the results. The final file (in JPEG format) will be generated in the same folder than the original image or your ‘Images’ folder, depending on your settings in the preferences. Watch as your memories develop.  Change the destination folder. If you will be doing a lot of pictures, it might be a good idea to have them all go into the same place. To do that, click on the blue icon  and go to Settings. Make your adjustments there.
